unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Determining a $p$-Value
question_text:
A group of college students in a psychology class wonders if the order of treatments changes the outcome of a study.
To test this, they ask students in a blind taste test which of two colas they prefer, Pepsi or Coke. In this blind taste test, the first $50\text{ randomly chosen subjects}$ are given Pepsi and then Coke, with $34$ preferring Pepsi. The next $50\text{ randomly chosen subjects}$ are given Coke and then Pepsi, with $29$ preferring Pepsi.
Does this give evidence that the order in which colas, or options, are presented makes a difference?
Determine the approximate $p$-value of a test to answer this question.
solution:
Find the test statistic by using a TI-83/84 calculator to see $z = 1.04$ or use the formula below where:

${ p }_{ 1 }= \dfrac{34}{50} = 0.68$
${ p }_{ 2 }= \dfrac{29}{50} = 0.58$
${ n }_{ 1 }= 50$
${ n }_{ 2 }= 50$

$$z= \dfrac{\hat{p_1} - \hat{p_2}}{\sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p}\left(\dfrac{1}{n_1} + \dfrac{1}{n_2}\right)}}$$

Pooled $\hat{p} = \dfrac{(34+29)}{(50+50)} = 0.63$

Using the standard normal table, $\text{P(z >1.04)} = 0.1492$.

Since this is a two-sided test, the $p$-value is $0.1492 \cdot 2 = 0.2984$.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'E'.

Note: On the AP test, the formula's listed are not given in their entirety. However, it is given on the test that a test statistic is found by:
(statistic - parameter) / standard deviation of statistic. Furthermore, the standard deviation formula is given on the AP test as well. A student only needs to put the pieces together rather than simply memorize a formula.
